title: Severe Bleeding Control
summary: How to control severe, life-threatening bleeding from wounds using direct pressure and other techniques.

steps.title: Ensure Safety and Call for Help
steps.description: Put on gloves if available. Call 911 for severe bleeding. Have the injured person lie down and keep them calm.

steps.title: Apply Direct Pressure
steps.description: Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to apply firm, continuous pressure directly on the wound. Do not remove the cloth if it becomes soaked - add more layers on top.

steps.title: Elevate the Injured Area
steps.description: If possible, raise the injured body part above the level of the heart while maintaining pressure. This helps reduce blood flow to the area.

steps.title: Apply a Pressure Bandage
steps.description: Once bleeding slows, apply a firm bandage over the dressing. The bandage should be snug but not cut off circulation. Check for pulse beyond the bandage.

steps.title: Use a Tourniquet if Necessary
steps.description: Only for life-threatening limb bleeding that won't stop with direct pressure. Apply 2-3 inches above the wound, tighten until bleeding stops. Note the time and do not remove.

warnings: Do not remove objects embedded in wounds - stabilize them in place
Do not apply tourniquet directly over a joint
Never use a tourniquet for more than 2 hours without medical supervision
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink
whenToSeekHelp: Bleeding that won't stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure
Signs of shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, confusion
Large or deep wounds, or wounds on head, neck, chest, or abdomen
preventionTips: Keep first aid supplies readily available
Use protective equipment when using tools or machinery
